indicators.justification:
There is no open data about greenhouse gas emissions. The official website of the Environment Protection agency has a special open data section, however, it is completely empty (1). Though not in open data, information about air pollution indicators is available on the Official Statistic Portal (2) or in the National Inventory Submissions reports, published by the United Nations (3). Open data portal though contains data about air pollution, but only on a very small scale as data covers only one regional town, Klaipeda (4).

(1): Environment Protection Agency, official website, https://aaa.lrv.lt/lt/veiklos-sritys/tarsos-prevencija/informacija-apie-gautas-paraiskas-tarsos-leidimams-gauti-pakeisti-sprendimai-del-paraiskos-priemimo/raseiniu-zuvininkyste (2): Air Pollution Indicators, the Official Statistic Portal, official website, https://osp.stat.gov.lt/statistiniu-rodikliu-analize?theme=all#/ (3): National Inventory Submissions reports, Lithuania, 2020, United Nations, https://unfccc.int/ghg-inventories-annex-i-parties/2020 (4): Air Pollution Data for Klaipeda, open data portal, official website, https://data.gov.lt/dataset/aplinkos-oro-monitoringo-duomenys

indicators.justification:
The company beneficial ownership information is not available as structured open data (1). Information about corporate performance and ownership might be acquired only if purchased (2) from the state-owned enterprise Centre of Registers (3). Data that is stored there covers all sectors nationally but is not available online. Civil society groups have been advocating (4)(5) for opening beneficial ownership data for the public but no results so far.

SOURCES:
(1): Open Data Portal, official website, https://data.gov.lt 
(2): Prices for Access to Information, State Enterprise Centre of Registers, official website, https://www.registrucentras.lt/p/45 
(3): https://info.registrucentras.lt/node/713 
(4): Open Data and Political Integrity in the Nordic Region, Transparency International Latvia, Transparency International Lithuania, Open Knowledge Sweden, 2019, https://www.transparency.lt/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/Open_Data_Report.pdf 
(5): Open Data Opening, business portal vz.lt, https://www.vz.lt/verslo-aplinka/2020/10/29/atverti-duomenu-atverima

indicators.justification:
Information about births, mortality rates, health, geographic location, etc. is public and available online in the Official Statistics Portal (1). However, it is not available in open data, thus all negative scorings. The Official Statistics Portal has a special section on open data (2), but it is very limited in scope and provides datasets only from Labour Force Survey, Income and Living Conditions Survey, Household Budget Survey, ICT use in households, Adult Education Survey, Structure of Earnings Survey, the Health Interview Survey, GIS data and COVID-19 related data.

indicators.justification:
Article 42 of the Law on Real Estate Registry states that real estate (which includes land) tenure data is public, except historical data which might be provided only to its owners, law enforcement and public sector institutions, journalists (1).

Though public, land tenure data might not be acquired free of charge. For this reason, negative scores apply. Also, if land owners are natural persons, it is not possible to know who exactly owns the land. As the Centre of Registries informs, purchasing this information only allows to see the fact that owners are natural persons (2). 

Costs for acquiring data are regulated by the Provisions of Real Estate Registry (3).

SOURCES:
(1): The Law on Real Estate Registry, No. I-1539, 1996, https://www.e-tar.lt/portal/lt/legalAct/TAR.38E82AA2664C/asr (2): Land datasets, The Centre of Registries, official website, https://info.registrucentras.lt/content/5665 (3): The Provisions of Real Estate Registry, 379, 2014, https://www.e-tar.lt/portal/lt/legalAct/ce127200d06011e3a8ded1a0f5aff0a9/asr

indicators.justification:
The Ministry of Finance launched an open data portal (1) that includes 12 large-scale financial datasets for each of the 60 municipalities in Lithuania (2). Data covers topics ranging from revenue and expenses of state and municipal institutions, to debts, income, and unemployment, and cover the period 2018-2021. Financial datasets from national-level bodies include all public and private recipients, such as corporations, small or medium businesses, and NGOs that received public funding for goods or services they provided. However, in cases, natural persons receive state funding they are not disclosed. 

SOURCES:
(1): Open Data Portal on Public Finances, official website, https://lietuvosfinansai.lt (2): Financial datasets, Open Data Portal on Public Finances, official website, https://rinkiniai.lietuvosfinansai.lt

indicators.justification:
Open data initiatives are still vague and usually emerge on the national stage. In 2020-2021 Lithuania witnessed an increasing number of open data efforts, starting from the launch of an open data portal (1) to the Public Procurement Office releasing data about the COVID-19 - related purchases (2). However, very few initiatives come from the local or municipal level. As confirmed by the Information Society Development Committee, only a limited number of public agencies are capable of opening data at least to some extend (3).
Zarasai, Kaunas, Klaipėda, Biržai, Druskininkai municipalities are among the few that provided data to open data portal (4).

SOURCES:

indicators.justification:
Directive (EU) 2015/849 (1) obligates Lithuania as well as other EU states to create registries for beneficial ownership data. This requirement is
transposed into Lithuania's national law through the Law on Prevention of Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing (2), which states that all legal entities have to submit information about their beneficial owners to the Information System of Participants of Legal Entities (in Lithuanian: JADIS) (3). Although Article 25, which stipulates this obligation, entered into force in 2019, Lithuania still has not implemented its provisions and no registry of this kind is created.

SOURCES:

(1): Directive (EU) 2015/849 of the European Parliament and of the Council on the prevention of the use of the financial system for the purposes of money laundering or terrorist financing, amending Regulation (EU) No 648/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council, and repealing Directive 2005/60/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council and Commission Directive 2006/70/EC, 
https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/PDF/?uri=CELEX:32015L0849&from=EN (2): The Law on Prevention of Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing, No. VIII-275, 1997, https://e-seimas.lrs.lt/portal/legalAct/lt/TAD/TAIS.41300/asr  (3): The System for Legal Persons, State Enterprise Centre of Registers, official website, https://www.registrucentras.lt/p/33

indicators.justification:
The open data framework for data sharing stands on three main pillars: a) the Law on Access to Information from State and Municipal institutions (1), which was updated in July 2021 to include a new provision about sharing data with the public. At the time of writing, the Law was still not enforced, though confirmed in the Parliament; b) the Decree on Approving the Recommendations for Open Data (2) that guides institutions on how to open data and share it in a user-friendly manner; c) The Law on the Management of Information Resources which foresees that public sector institutions might acquire data from public registries free of charge, contrary to everyone else who needs to pay for it.

SOURCES:

(1): The Law on the Changes of the Law on Access to Information from State and Municipal institution, No. XIV-491, 2021, https://e-seimas.lrs.lt/portal/legalAct/lt/TAD/77d2b640dd6711eb866fe2e083228059?jfwid=-1cefbqlfhs (2): The Law on Public Administration, No. VIII-1234, 1999, https://www.e-tar.lt/portal/lt/legalAct/2bf2218048d311eb8d9fe110e148c770 (3): The Law on the Management of Information Resources, No. XI-1807, 2011, https://www.e-tar.lt/portal/lt/legalAct/TAR.85C510BA700A/asr

indicators.justification:
The Law on Budget Structure (Article 11) states that both planned and confirmed national and municipal budgets are public (1), however, there are no requirements to publish financial information in open data formats. The Decree of the Minister of Economy and Innovations that provides recommendations for open data, does not include provisions for financial data disclosure (2). 

SOURCES:
(1): The Law on Budget Structure, No. I-430, 1990, https://e-seimas.lrs.lt/portal/legalAct/lt/TAD/TAIS.428/asr (2): The Decree of the Minister of Economy and Innovations 'Reccomendations for Opening Public Sector's data', No. 4-1150, 2020, https://www.e-tar.lt/portal/lt/legalAct/2bf2218048d311eb8d9fe110e148c770

indicators.justification:
Both the Law on the Adjustment of Public and Private Interests in the Civil Service (No.VIII-371, 1997) (1) and the Law on Asset Declaration (No. I-1338, 1996) (2) oblige public officials to disclose positions held, firm ownership, shares in public or private companies if those shares enable decision making within companies in question. They and their spouses or partners have to declare their assets, including art work, jewellery, precious metals which value exceeds 1 500 EUR (2). 

Data quality received negative scoring as there are no requirements to provide information about interest and assets in open data formats. 

SOURCES:
(1): The Law on the Adjustment of Public and Private Interests in the Civil Service, No.VIII-371, 1997, https://e-seimas.lrs.lt/portal/legalAct/lt/TAD/TAIS.41669/asr (2): The Law on Asset Declaration, No. I-1338, 1996, https://e-seimas.lrs.lt/portal/legalAct/lt/TAD/TAIS.27942/asrProvisions for data quality:

indicators.justification:
In 2020, the Lithuanian parliament adopted a new Law on Lobbying Activities (No. VIII-1749, 2000) and for the first time establishing the so-called "cross-declaration" (1). It requires both lobbyists, and politicians and public servants who have contact with lobbyists to report lobbying activities. Lobbyists also have to register and electronically submit activity reports to a special lobbyist platform SKAIDRIS (2). However, the register still presents some flaws. The data is not available in machine-readable format and it has empty sections (2). Lobbyists do not fill their reports fully as it is visible from their online activity reports.

SOURCES:
(1): The Law on Lobbying Activities, No. VIII-1749, 2000, https://e-seimas.lrs.lt/portal/legalAct/lt/TAD/TAIS.104674/asr (2): The Lobbying Registry SKAIDRIS, official website, https://skaidris.vtek.lt/public/home/main

indicators.justification:
The Law on Political campaign finance and finance control obliges to make all financial contracts, financial and audit reports available for the public (1). Article 10 obliges financial managers of political campaigns to inform Central Electoral Commission about individual donors - natural persons - and insert their names and surnames into the online donors' list (2). 

Political campaigns and advertising are described in the Law on Political campaign finance and finance control, however, grey zones still exist. This leads to investigations, trying to unveil if certain publicity events or public appearances were in line with legal regulations (3) (4). 

SOURCES:
(1): The Law on Political campaign finance and finance control, No. IX-2428, 2004, https://www.e-tar.lt/portal/lt/legalAct/TAR.CF812DA6E814/asr (2): Voter's Page, official website of the Central Electoral Commission, https://www.rinkejopuslapis.lt/ataskaitu-formavimas (3): CEC will discuss about possible political advertising at Naisiu summer, news portal lrt.lt, https://www.lrt.lt/naujienos/lietuvoje/2/219586/vrk-spres-ar-naisiu-vasaroje-buvo-politines-reklamos (4): Political Advertising on Social Platforms, Transparency International Lithuania, 2020, https://www.transparency.lt/sutarkime-ka-socialiniuose-tinkluose-laikome-politine-reklama/

indicators.justification:
The Law on Law-making (No. XI-2220, 2012) regulated public consultations and makes them compulsory when 'significant' changes within the legal framework are registered and discussed (1). It states that institutions are free to decide on the form of public consultations and how their results will be presented (2), however, this information should be available online in a special TAIS system (2).
The Office of the Government has admitted that Lithuania lacks a common standard for public consultations which was again repeated in the new Program of the Government (3). Updating regulations for public consultations and strengthening its methodological approach were included in Government's agenda for 2020-2024 (3).

SOURCES:
(1): The Law on Law-making, No. XI-2220, 2012, https://e-seimas.lrs.lt/portal/legalAct/lt/TAD/TAIS.433088/asr (2): The Decree of the Justice Ministry on the Information System for Law-making, No. 1R-312, 2013, https://e-seimas.lrs.lt/portal/legalAct/lt/TAD/TAIS.463688?jfwid=-98jkh9cf7 (3): The Action Plan of the Government for the Government's Programme 2020-2024, https://lrv.lt/uploads/main/documents/files/VPNĮP%20projektas.pdf

indicators.justification:
The framework regulates how public sector institutions react upon receiving complaints (1) or freedom of information requests (1) (2), however does not have provisions for managing information about the services provided in open data formats. The framework does not require to collect and publish information or data regarding the time consumed to answer the requests, material withheld and the reasons for withholding it.

indicators.justification:
Civic organisations and media use data for their research, advocacy campaigns or investigations, however, only most often their work is based on data requested rather than opened data (1) (2) (3).

Data use does not necessarily lead to positive impact, though long lasting advocacy efforts made Parliament open its data (4). Most often, on the contrary, data use calls out negative reactions. For instance, in 2020 the Supreme Administrative Court ruled that the move of the Office of the Government to deny access to an audio recording of ministers discussing access to registry data was unlawful and violated media's rights (5). Institutions tend to deny access to open data arguing it is against General Data Protection Regulation (6). 

SOURCES:
(1): Public platform Karstospedos.lt, investigative media SIENA, official website, https://karstospedos.lt/duomenys.html (2): THE UPDATED MANOSEIMAS.LT WEBSITE PROVIDES AN OPPORTUNITY TO FIND OUT WHO PARTICIPATED IN THE DISCUSSIONS ON 865 PIECES OF LEGISLATION IN COMMITTEES DURING THE LAST PARLIAMENTARY TERM, https://www.transparency.lt/en/committees/ (3): LAST YEAR 43 POLITICIANS, STATE OFFICIALS AND THEIR SPOUSES OWNED 83 MEDIA OUTLETS, Transparency International Lithuania, 2020, https://www.transparency.lt/en/media-owners-2020/ (4): Open data, Lithuanian Parliament, official website, https://www.google.com/url?sa=t&rct=j&q=&esrc=s&source=web&cd=&cad=rja&uact=8&ved=2ahUKEwjoqMOp7fvxAhXLlYsKHXJFBg4QFjAAegQIBRAD&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.lrs.lt%2Fsip%2Fportal.show%3Fp_r%3D35391%26p_k%3D1&usg=AOvVaw0_08DlZhVHVysqr2NA752Z (5): The Office of the Government says it respects Court's Decision, news portal delfi.lt, https://www.delfi.lt/news/daily/lithuania/vyriausybes-kanceliarija-sako-gerbianti-teismo-sprendima-del-sunaikinto-garso-iraso.d?id=84839747 (6): Public Discussion on GDPR, The National Forum on Human Rights, 2020, https://nztf.lt/en/#0

indicators.justification:
Both Public Procurement Office has said numerous times (1) (2) that open data helped them raise red flags and assisted in identifying certain loopholes within the system. Investigative journalists and civil society worked with open procurement data to analyse financial flows. For instance, Transparency International Lithuania used public procurement data to find out that during the first wave of COVID-19, monitoring authorities and decision-makers may not have been aware of 10% of all the money spent on fighting the pandemic (3). 

SOURCES:
(1): Buy open, buy fast: how open contracting helped Lithuania's Coronavirus response, blog post, 2021, Open Contracting Partnership, https://www.open-contracting.org/2021/03/30/buy-open-buy-fast-how-open-contracting-helped-lithuanias-coronavirus-response/  (2): Report on COVID-19 procurement: Open Data, Loopholes and Recommendations, official website, Public Procurement Office, https://vpt.lrv.lt/lt/naujienos/vpt-parengta-covid-19-pirkimu-ataskaita-atviri-duomenys-nustatyti-pirkimu-trukumai-ir-rekomendacijos (3): Findings and recommendations for better emergency procurement from 12 countries, Open Contracting Partnership, 2020, https://www.open-contracting.org/resources/action-research-lessons-covid19/
